A dual acidic hydrothermally stable MOF-composite for upgrading xylose to furfural Amrita Chatterjee Xijun Hu Frank Leung-Yuk Lam ⁎ Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Sai Kung, Hong Kong SAR, China Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering Hong Kong University of Science and Technology Sai Kung Hong Kong SAR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This work presents the development of a new hybrid material composed of metal-organic-framework, MIL-101 (Cr) and mesoporous tin phosphate nanoparticles. The phosphate groups of the composite impart Brønsted acidity, while the Cr and Sn atoms act as the Lewis acid sites, thus promoting it as a dual acid functionalized material suitable for solid acid catalysis of biomass. Simultaneously, the issues of hydrothermal stability and degradation in acidic medium as faced by pristine MIL-101 (Cr), have been fairly alleviated. In order to demonstrate our claims, the composite has been used as a solid acid catalyst for the dehydration of xylose to furfural. A remarkable performance of 86.7% furfural yield with 92.3% selectivity has been achieved in 180 min at 150 °C. The composite can sustain minimum of 10 cycles of run while pristine MIL-101 (Cr) loses its functional properties after 4 cycles of run. In presence of 35 ppt NaCl solution, the yield and selectivity improved to 92.4% and 96.6% respectively. Keywords Xylose dehydration Dual acid Metal organic framework Composite Hydrothermal stability 1 Introduction The versatility of metal-organic-frameworks (MOFs) in tailoring their functional groups and pore sizes have made them attractive materials as selective catalysts for various redox reactions. Biomass valorization reactions like dehydration or esterification have water as the reaction medium or generated as products. Therefore, a hydrothermally stable MOF is a suitable choice for such catalytic processes. MOFs such as MIL-53 (Al), MIL-101 (Cr), UIO-66, UIO-67 have been identified as hydrothermally stable MOFs. In spite of their high Lewis acidity, these MOFs lack enough Brønsted acidity to be used as effective catalysts for sugar dehydration reactions [1–3]. The most common method of introducing Brønsted acidity to MOFs is by post synthetic modifications where sulfonic acid groups are introduced. Some of the successfully developed Brønsted acid MOFs include: polyoxometals encapsulated in HKUST-1 and MIL-101 (Cr), controlled sulfated MOF-808 or post synthetically acidified UIO-66 [4–7]. Drawbacks of such strategies are that it compromises with the stability and crystallinity of the MOFs. Further, a robust MOF structure is required to successfully implement the post-synthetic method. Acid impregnated MIL-101 (Cr) synthesized by Ponomareva et al. suffers from leaching [8]. One of the established method to impart functionalities to existing materials is to develop composites by adding suitable external synthetic components. To improve the hydrothermal stability of MOFs, researches have been carried out to make MOF composites by adding CNTs, activated carbon, attapulgite clay, SBA-15, graphite oxide etc. [9–13]. Though successful in their endeavor of improving the hydrothermal stability, these composites have not been able to enhance the Brønsted acidity simultaneously. Recent works have established MIL-101 (Cr) as a promising catalyst for dehydration of hexose sugars to furan compounds [14–16]. Cr3+ have also been identified as the driving species for xylose to furfural transformations [17,18]. However, MIL-101 (Cr) did not provide satisfactory results when used for xylose dehydration reaction at a higher temperature of 150–170 °C (this work). Lack of Brønsted acid sites in MIL-101 (Cr) reduce the furfural selectivity. Also, our experiments show that the MOF degraded after 4 cycles of reaction run. Hence it is necessary to enhance the Brønsted acidity of MOFs simultaneously with the hydrothermal stability. In this work, mesoporous tin phosphate has been used to form a composite with MIL-101 (Cr). The applications of mesoporous metal phosphates such as, NbP, ZrP, TaP, SAPO, SnP in biomass valorization have been quite popular [19–25]. The mesostructured transition metal phosphates combine the redox and/or acid-base features along with the porosity of the materials for easy diffusion of reactants and products. The stability is of these mesoporous metal phosphates is considerably high [26]. In spite of the continuous endeavors to maximize the yield and selectivity of furfural in the xylose dehydration reaction at a low temperature, the existing literatures show that the yield of furfural obtained in heterogeneously catalyzed reactions at temperature below 200 °C normally range from 60 to 78% [27]. Tin phosphate has been selected as the desired material to be composited with MOF, because, it is hydrothermally stable, and the P-OH species act as strong Brønsted acid sites which enable better selectivity towards furfural. The mesoporous tin phosphate-MIL-101 (Cr) hybrid is not only more hydrothermally stable than pure MIL-101 (Cr), but also, provide higher furfural yield at a lower temperature than either of MIL-101(Cr) or tin phosphate when used individually. Till date, discrete metal nanoparticles (Au, Pd, Ru, Ag, Pt etc.) have been used as the additional component to tune properties of MOFs [28]. For the first time, this work introduces the property enhancement effects when acid-functionalized compound nanoparticles serve as the composite component. Thereby, we have also developed a new way to increase Brønsted acidity in MOFs, without affecting its crystalline structure or hydrothermal stability. 2 Materials and methods The reagents used are chromium (III) nitrate nonahydrate (99%), terephthalic acid (98%), glacial acetic acid (99.7% ACS reagent), ethanol (96%), tin (IV) chloride pentahydrate (99.99%), Pluronic P123 (Poly(ethylene-glycol)-block-poly(propylene-glycol)-block-poly(ethylene-glycol)), ortho-phosphoric acid (85%, AnalaR Normapur ACS grade), D-(+)-xylose (minimum 99%), toluene (AnalaR Normapur ACS grade), furfural (99% ACS grade), sodium chloride (>99% ACS reagent). All these reagents are obtained from Sigma Aldrich and have been used without further purification unless otherwise stated. 2.1 Catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 Synthesis of MIL-101 (Cr) MIL-101 (Cr) is synthesized by a modified hydrothermal method without using the corrosive hydrofluoric acid. The procedure involves mixing 4 g Cr(NO3)2·9H2O, 1.66 g terephthalic acid, 0.58 mL glacial acetic acid and 50 mL water in a Teflon container, and heating the solution for 8 h at 220 °C. The material obtained is filtered with a large pore fitted glass filter followed by refluxing with ethanol at 80 °C for 24 h. A total of 200 mL ethanol is used per gram of MIL-101 (Cr). The as-synthesized MIL-101 (Cr) is further dried at 150 °C in vacuum to remove water adsorbed in the pores. Nearly 70% of the product is recovered based on the weight of the salt used [29]. 2.1.2 Synthesis of mesoporous tin (iv) phosphate (SnP) The mesoporous tin phosphate is prepared by using a slightly modified method following the procedure by Dutta et al. Briefly, 1 g Pluronic P123 is dissolved into 10 mL water and subsequently a total of 10 mmol phosphoric acid is added to the mixture. The solution is stirred for 2 h and 10 mmol of tin (IV) chloride pentahydrate is further added to obtain white colloidal precipitate. The mixture is then stirred for another 2 h period and is heated at 100 °C for 48 h. The white mass obtained after cooling is filtered and dried followed by calcination at 550 °C for 4 h at a ramping rate of 1 K/min [25]. 2.1.3 Synthesis of SnP-MIL-101 (Cr)-composite (MP) To prepare the composite, pre-calculated amount of SnP is mixed into a 50 mL aqueous solution containing 1.66 g terephthalic acid and 0.58 mL glacial acetic acid. After 30 min of stirring, 4 g Cr (NO3)2·9H2O is added to the solution and heated at 220 °C for 8 h. The washing procedure followed is same as that during synthesis of MIL-101 (Cr). The composites are prepared using 1 g, 2 g and 3.5 g SnP and named as MP-1, MP-2 and MP-3 accordingly [11,30]. 2.2 Characterizations of the developed catalysts The bulk elemental analysis of the developed catalysts is performed by the X-ray fluorescence instrument JEOL JSX-3201Z. The corresponding crystalline structure of the prepared catalysts are determined from X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, which are conducted by a PANalytical powder X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu-Kα radiation source (wavelength of 1.54 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Chemical states of the elements in the developed catalysts are determined from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using Kratos Axis Ultra DLD and the DRIFT-UV–vis spectra collected using Perkin-Elmer Lambda 950 UV–vis NIR spectrophotometer. In order to analyze the inorganic species of the developed catalysts, the solid state 31P MAS-NMR is performed using JNM-ECZ 500R/S1 using a field strength of 11 T. To evaluate the functional groups of the developed catalysts, Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy is performed in a Bruker Vertex 70 instrument using KBr in the sample preparation. The surface area and pore volume of the developed catalysts are determined by nitrogen physisorption measurement carried out at 77 K using a Coulter SA 3100 surface area and pore size analyzer. The samples are degassed at 150 °C for 2 h prior to nitrogen adsorption. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of the synthesized catalysts is done in Setaram TGA 92-16.18, where the sample is placed under N2 flow and heated from ambient conditions to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. For morphological study, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis is conducted by the unit of JEOL-2010. To determine the total number of acid sites in the developed catalysts, ammonia temperature-programmed-desorption (NH3-TPD) is performed by Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 using NH3-16 as the probe molecule. Prior to the adsorption of NH3, the samples are degassed with helium at 180 °C. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy with pyridine as probe molecule has been performed by Nicolet 6700 to identify the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. The samples are first degassed at 180 °C for 2 h, followed by pyridine adsorption at 25 °C for 1 h. Removal of physisorbed pyridine is performed at 150 °C for 30 min and the spectra is collected after conducting desorption at 150 °C for 1 h. The metal leaching of the spent catalyst is examined by characterizing the aqueous phase of the post-reaction effluent by inductively coupled plasma with mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS Varian 820). 2.3 Catalytic evaluation of the organic transformation of D-xylose to furfural The catalytic dehydration of xylose has been performed in a batch mode operation using a 100-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor. In a typical experiment, a total of 300 mg of D-xylose, pre-determined amount of catalyst, 3 mL of water and 7 mL of toluene are added to the reactor. It is heated to 150 °C in an oven and kept at the same temperature for 3 h [31]. At the completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture in the autoclave is centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 15 min to separate the catalyst containing aqueous phase and furfural-rich toluene phase. A control experiment, in the absence of catalyst, has been performed to compare the effectiveness of the developed composite. To study the effect of NaCl towards xylose dehydration reaction, various concentrations of sodium chloride solutions are prepared and used as the reaction media. The used catalyst is washed with toluene and dried in a vacuum oven at 150 °C to remove the moisture and the residues from the surface of the catalyst. The dried catalyst is re-used for the next reactions to evaluate its durability test. 2.4 Analysis of the reaction products The furfural rich toluene phase is quantitatively determined using an Agilent Technologies gas chromatogram equipped with an Alltech Aquawax capillary column (30 m  × 0.25 mm  × 0.25 μm). The aqueous phase containing the un-reacted xylose is analyzed using a Waters 2695 HPLC equipped with a Biorad Aminex HPX-87P carbohydrate analysis column. De-ionized water is used as the eluent. A total of 1.0 μL of the aqueous phase of the sample volume is analyzed. 3 Results and discussion The XRF elemental analysis of the developed catalysts in Table S1 shows that the bulk concentrations of Sn and P increase with the higher proportion of SnP added to the composite. The slight amount of Fe present in MIL-101 (Cr) could be due to the contamination from the steel reactors. The XRD pattern in Fig. 1 shows the characteristic peaks of cubic structure of MIL-101 (Cr). The peaks at 2θ = 3.31°, 3.97°, 5.18°, 5.91°, 9.07°, 10.34°, 16.92°, 17.28°, 19.55° correspond to the Miller indices of (0 1 1), (0 0 4), (1 3 3), (1 3 5), (1 9 5), (2 2 10), (4 4 16), (10 10 10), (8 8 16), accordingly [32]. The XRD pattern of SnP does not possess any distinct peak because of its amorphous nature. The small angle XRD of SnP in Fig. S1 exhibits a broad peak at 0.66°, which corresponds to the inter-pore distance of 10.22 nm [25]. This broad peak indicates the mesoporous structure of the SnP [33]. The similarity of the XRD patterns of the composites with the MIL-101 (Cr) prove that the MOF structure is retained in the composite [11]. The presence of Cr, Sn and P on the surface of the composites is evident from the presence of their peaks in the overall XPS spectra in Fig. S2(a). As reported in Table 1 , the relative atomic concentration of Sn and P increases with addition of SnP nanoparticles, demonstrating the successful hybridization of the nanoparticles with the MOFs in the composites. It is evident from Fig. S2(b) that the peaks of Sn 3d 5/2 and Sn 3d 3/2 in SnP are located at 485.3 eV and 493.8 eV, respectively. The binding energy (B.E.) difference of ∼8.5 eV between the peaks confirms the oxidation state of tin as Sn4+ [34]. The oxidation state of Sn4+ is retained even after the composite formation. It is concluded from Fig. S2(c) that the chemical state of Cr (III) is unaltered in the composites. This is confirmed from the peaks of Cr 2p 3/2 and Cr 2p 1/2 at B.E of 576.9 eV and 586.5 eV, respectively [35,36]. The C1s spectrum in Fig. 2 (a), consist of the organic benzene ring carbon positioned at 284.9 eV and the carboxyl groups in pristine MIL-101 (Cr) at 288.8 eV. The peak of carboxyl group shifts from 288.8 to 289.5 eV because of the interaction between the POH and CO groups during formation of the composite, MP-2 [37,38]. The P 2p spectrum in Fig. S2(d) reveals that the phosphate in SnP is in SnOP and POH forms at 132.5 eV and 133.7 eV, respectively and the corresponding phosphorus is present in as the P5+ in the structure. The higher B.E value of POH at 133.7 eV occurs due to the presence of polar PO groups, which are bound to surface hydroxyls [22,24,39]. The peak at 134.3 eV in Fig. S2(e) confirms the bond formation between carboxyl and POH groups in MP-2 [40–42]. Fig. S2(f) depicts that the oxygen atom in SnP primarily constitutes the mesoporous framework of tin in form of SnOP and the POH groups are indicated from peaks at 531.6 eV and 532.6 eV, respectively [43–45]. No peak for POP has been detected since the calcination temperature used is low enough to prevent condensation of the POH groups [46]. The peak of POC at 533.3 eV in Fig. 2(b) provides evidence of the bond formation between the carboxyl group of terephthalic acid and hydroxylgroups of SnP [47]. No oxygen from adsorbed water has been detected from the composite owing to its hydro-stable nature, where the Cr (III) atoms are shielded by the SnP particle from getting attacked by water molecules. Table S2 provide the B.E values of the resolved peaks of the developed catalysts. The UV-VIS spectrum of MIL-101 (Cr) in Fig. 3 shows three peaks at 270 nm, 450 nm, and 601 nm, which are characteristics of Cr3+ valence state in the distorted octahedral form [48]. The SnP shows only a sharp peak at 220 nm, confirming the existence of Sn4+ in its tetrahedral coordination [33]. Presence of four distinct peaks corresponding to 220 nm, 270 nm, 450 nm, and 601 nm in the composite proves that the state of Cr in the framework remains intact even after synthesizing the composite, while the Sn4+ of the SnP nanoparticles get incorporated in the MOF. The tetrahedral coordination of Sn4 + is responsible for the additional Lewis acidic properties of the composite, apart from the acidity imparted by the Cr (III) species. Fig. 4 exhibits that the solid state 31P MAS NMR spectra of SnP has a broad signal centered at the chemical shift of -9.8 ppm, indicating the presence of phosphorus in (H2PO4)− state. However, the composite MP-2 shows two peaks at −9.6 ppm and −12.7 ppm, corresponding to the (H2PO4)− and (HPO4)2- states of phosphorus respectively. The protonation of some of the POH groups of SnP during reaction with carboxylic groups of terephthalic acid cause condensation of (H2PO4)− to (HPO4)2−. Therefore the composite is a medley of (H2PO4)− and (HPO4)2− [22,49,50]. The surface terminated POH groups impart the strong Brønsted acidity to the composites. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the developed catalysts in Fig. 5 provide an insight on their textural properties. According to the IUPAC nomenclature, the type IV isotherm of SnP with H1 hysteresis loop, indicate its narrow pore size distribution. The pristine MOF, MIL-101 (Cr) has a type IV isotherm, with high uptake of nitrogen at low pressure of P/P0 < 0.1, due to the presence of wide range of micropores [25,32]. The presence of large mesoporous cages with pentagonal and hexagonal microporous windows in MIL-101 (Cr) is evident from uptake of nitrogen at 0.14 < P/P0 < 0.25. Reduction of the pore volume and surface area are observed after addition of SnP due to the coverage of the surface pores of the MOF crystals by the encapsulated SnP nanoparticles [51,52]. The TEM image corroborates the same. The isotherms of composites show significant hysteresis loop of type H4 at higher relative pressures because of the presence of large sized (∼7.5 nm) mesopores contributed from the SnP particles. Possibly new mesopores arise at the interface of SnP and MOF, though the interfacial pores cannot be verified [30]. Table 2 summarizes the pore size and pore volume of the developed catalysts. The FTIR spectrum in Fig. 6 shows that the mesoporous SnP has two peaks at 550 cm−1 and 630 cm−1 corresponding to the bending vibrations produced from PO2 moieties. The symmetrical stretching vibrations of PO that arise from PO4 3- of SnOP networks are confirmed from the peak at 1041 cm−1. Presence of hydrogen phosphate is confirmed from the peak at 1242 cm−1. The peak at 1630 cm−1 is attributed to the bending vibrations of the water molecules. The surface hydroxyl groups bound by hydrogen bonds give rise to the broad peak at 3440 cm−1. Absence of peaks at 750 cm−1 in SnP confirm the absence of POP in the samples [25,33,53,54]. In pristine MIL-101 (Cr), the bands between 600 and 1600 cm−1 occur due to the stretching and deformation vibrations of the benzene rings of the organic linker terephthalic acid. The deformation vibration of CH gives rise to peaks at 750, 884, 1017, 1160 cm−1. The CC stretching vibration of benzene is confirmed from the peak at 1508 cm−1. The peaks at 1402–1621 cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric stretching of carboxylate ions due to the carboxylate linkage of the terephthalic acid to the Cr atoms. The peak at 1621 cm−1 may be attributed to the adsorbed water in the MIL-101 (Cr) crystals [55,56]. In the composite catalysts, with increasing amount of SnP, the peaks at 1041 cm−1 and 1242 cm−1 increase in intensity due to the enhanced incorporation of the phosphate groups in the composite. At the same time, the peaks at 1402–1621 cm−1 reduce in intensity and broaden. This deformation of the asymmetric stretching of the carboxylate ions occur due to the attachment of the POH groups to the carboxylic species of MOF. The peak broadening and deformation of the adsorbed water peak at 1621 cm−1 prove that after the composite formation, less coordination of water species to the Cr atoms is expected, thus making them more thermally stable. The surface acidity of the catalysts has been analyzed by the ammonia-TPD and pyridine-FTIR. The ammonia-TPD results illustrated in Fig. 7 (a) suggest that the MIL-101 (Cr) is composed of weak acid sites, moderately strong acid sites and some strong acid sites, which desorb ammonia at 112 °C, 263 °C and 320 °C respectively [57]. The concentration of strong acid sites is very high in SnP which desorbs ammonia at 380 °C. The composites have higher concentration of strong acid sites at 370 °C, which are responsible for the improved hydrolysis of the xylose molecules, than the pristine MIL-101 (Cr). The presence of the acid sites of Cr (III), Sn (IV), (H2PO4)− and (HPO4)2− in the composite improves the total acidity. In Fig. 7(b), the peaks at 1450 cm−1 and 1540 cm−1 indicate the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, respectively. The acid site concentrations in Table 3 have been computed by considering the molar extinction coefficient of Lewis and Brønsted acidity as 1.42 and 1.88 μmol cm−1, respectively [58]. The Lewis acid sites arise from the presence of Cr (III) sites of MIL-101 (Cr) and Sn (IV) sites of SnP, while the Brønsted acidity can be attributed to the phosphate groups (POH) of the mesoporous SnP. The peak at 1491 cm−1 can be explained as the weak Brønsted acidity contributed from the uncoordinated water molecules of MIL-101 (Cr) [1]. The thermo-gravimetric analysis in Fig. S3 shows that SnP nanoparticles have high thermal stability and starts to decompose above 600 °C. In comparison, MIL-101 (Cr) decomposes just above 350 °C. The initial 15% mass loss of pristine MIL-101 (Cr) is due to the release of free water molecules trapped inside the pores. The next 15% mass loss is attributed to the evaporation of crystallized water from the MOF structure. On heating above 350 °C, the structure starts collapsing due to the decomposition of the carboxyl groups forming the organic framework. Further heating leads to the formation of chromic oxide [32,59]. The TGA results demonstrate that the thermal stability of the composite is better than pristine MOF, but worse than SnP. The overall mass loss is 27.72% in MP-2 as compared to the 68.75% mass loss of MIL-101 (Cr). The thermal degradation of the framework of MP-2 starts at 410 °C. It is expected that the chelation of the metal atoms of the two individual materials give rise to a structure similar to POCO(Cr) in the hybrid material [11]. Such a modified structure improves stability of the composite MOFs. The TEM images in Fig. 8 show that particles of 1 nm diameter aggregate and form the interstitial mesopores in SnP. The pristine MIL-101 (Cr) crystals have diameter of ∼200–300 nm and they exist as the cubic shape as reported in literature [29]. The composite MP-2 clearly corresponds to the data obtained from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and XRD data, showing that the nanoparticles of SnP have block the pores and reduce the pore volume of MOF. The small size of the SnP nanoparticles enable them to block the pores of MOF easily. The EDS spectrum in Fig. S4 confirms the presence of Sn, Cr and P in the hybrid material as in agreement with XRF and XPS data. Characterizations of SnP confirm that the mesoporous material has H2PO4 2− as its acidic species. Therefore the possible structure of tin phosphate is likely to be shown as such form in Fig. S5(a) [39,50,60]. After the addition of terephthalic acid solution to the SnP, due to the difference in acidity of the carboxylic group and POH group, the organic ligands interact and attach to the surface of the SnP nanoparticles and form an intermediate, as depicted in Fig. S5(b) [9,11]. When chromium salt is added and heated under hydrothermal conditions, crystallization occurs, and the MIL-101 (Cr) crystals nucleate from the oversaturated solution and deposit on the surface surrounding the SnP nanoparticles as presented in Fig. S5(c) [61]. In the absence of catalyst, the yield of furfural at 150 °C is 8.2%. The yield increases to 48% and 40.3% in the presence of bare SnP and pristine MIL-101 (Cr) respectively. Fig. 9 (a) shows that the catalyst MP-2 provides the highest yield and selectivity of 86.7% and 92.4%, while MP-1 achieves only 63.4% yield and 79.1% selectivity. The increase in number of Lewis and Brønsted sites is responsible for the better performance of MP-2. Though the xylose conversion continues to increase, a decrease in furfural yield to 79% is observed when MP-3 with higher phosphate content is used as the catalyst. The excess number of strong acid sites of Sn4+ in MP-3 induce the side reactions which form humins and reduce the desired product. As the weight ratio of catalyst to reactant is increased, more number of active sites are accessible for the reaction and the yield improves. As shown in Fig. 9(b), a maximum yield is observed at 0.1 g MP-2. However, at a catalyst weight of 0.35 g, a slight decrease in yield is observed, and the detrimental effect continues when the catalyst amount is further increased. The poor diffusion of reactants and products within the catalyst due to the absence of stirring is responsible for such an effect. Further, cross-polymerization of unreacted sugars and product in aqueous medium lead to drop in selectivity. Fig. 9(c) illustrates that the conversion enhances with the reaction time at a certain temperature (150 °C). After a reaction time of 180 min, the xylose conversion reaches 93.8%, and the yield of furfural is 86.7%. Further increase in reaction time ensures the improvement in conversion of xylose, but the yield of furfural suffers. The reduction in yield is possibly due to two factors: (a) the self-polymerization of the furfural which has not been extracted to the organic phase and (b) the resin formation by reaction of furfural and xylose in the aqueous phase. According to most literature, the optimum reaction temperature for xylose dehydration is anywhere between 100–250 °C [27,62]. Too high temperature is undesired because of expenditure of energy, while too low temperature leads to poor product yield. For MP-2, a temperature of 150 °C has been found to be sufficient to provide the best result. The favorable effect of elevated temperature is depicted in Fig. 9(d). At a low temperature of 120 °C, the kinetic energy of the reactants is insufficient to overcome the activation energy barrier, hence the rate of furfural formation is slow and only 55.3% yield is achieved at the end of 180 min. At the temperature of 170 °C, the catalyst enables xylose conversion as high as 94.6% in 90 min, but the yield does not increase accordingly. At the elevated temperature, the backward reaction rate takes precedence over the forward reaction rate due to its lower activation energy. This causes humin formation and reduced selectivity to furfural [31,63–67]. Salts, like NaCl, are able to improve the partition coefficient of the biphasic system and facilitates better extraction of furfural by the toluene phase. This prevents the undesired polymerization reactions between furfural and xylose molecules in the water medium [25,31]. It is observed from Fig. 9(e) that when reaction is conducted in 35 ppt saline water, the yield and selectivity improve to 92.3% and 96.6%, respectively. This opens up a new possibility to use the sea water as the reaction medium, which may reduce the cost of production. The conversion of xylose to furfural is heavily dependent on the textural properties and acid site concentrations of the catalyst. The size of xylose and furfural molecule is 0.68 nm and 0.57 nm respectively [68]. Therefore, the pore size of the catalyst should be large enough in order to facilitate the mass transfer for both reactant and product molecules while interacting the active sites in the interior of the catalyst. A high surface area is desirable to enable more contact of the active sites with the reactant molecules, which in turn enhances the conversion of reactant and yield of product. The high surface area of MIL-101 (Cr) and presence of adequate number of Lewis acid sites in the form of unsaturated Cr (III) converts the xylose effectively but the yield of furfural is poor due to the absence of effective number of Brønsted acid sites. This increase in average pore size in the composites contributes to the better diffusion of xylose and furfural molecules from the pores of composite catalysts. It should also be noted that too small pore size may suffer from the pore blocking by the unwanted reaction intermediates during the reaction in the interior of MOF, resulting in poisoning the active sites and finally low product yield. Optimization of the amount of SnP present in the composite plays a major role. Therefore, MP-1 with low concentration of SnP, possess less Brønsted acidic P-OH species, which are not enough for dehydrating the xylose molecules. In MP-3 the average pore size is 4.1 nm. The pore volume and surface area are reduced in MP-3 due to pore blockage of MOF by encapsulation of excess number of SnP nanoparticles. The low porosity prevents the access of active sites and favors formation of bulky byproducts in the pores. Also, the presence of higher quantity of hard Lewis acidic Sn4+ encourages the polymerization of furfural to undesired side products. Choudhary et al. have reported that to conduct xylose dehydration reaction at lower temperature, a catalyst should possess an optimum ratio of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, instead of only one variety. From Fig. S6, it can be deduced that the one step direct conversion of xylose to furfural requires 32 kcal mol−1 energy, while the activation gets lowered to as low as 15.5 kcal mol−1, when the dual acid catalyst is used [17]. Based on the literature, the proposed reaction mechanism of the MP-2 catalyzed xylose dehydration reaction is depicted in Fig. S7. In the composite MP-2 the uncoordinated chromium sites Cr3+ and tethrahedrally coordinated Sn4+ act as the Lewis centers and the phosphate groups from as the Brønsted centers. These two Lewis acid sites act synergistically and form a complex chelate with the xylose to convert it into its isomer, xylulose. This isomerization takes place when the proton abstraction from O2 enables the formation of a [Cr (III)/ Sn (IV)] chelate with O2 and O1 of xylose molecule [17]. The two highly electron deficient species induce the proton abstraction and the bonds formed are elongated, which results in easy breakage or hydrolysis of xylulose in the consequent steps. Therefore, the synergistic Lewis acid effect achieves higher conversion than monometallic catalysts. This is followed by a hydride transfer from C2 to C1 and finally the charge of electronegative O1 is stabilized by donation of the proton back to it. The xylulose thus formed, undergoes protonation by the action of the POH groups and stabilizes the positively charged oxygen atom. The positive charge delocalizes leading to the dissociation of CO bond and eventually eliminating the water molecule. Likewise, three molecules of water liberate to form furfural as the main product [62]. Prevalent researches suggest that the conversion of xylose to furfural follows a pseudo first order kinetics with respect to the reactant xylose [63]. This assumption holds good when (1) furfural is the sole product of the dehydration reaction and (2) furfural is stable enough without undergoing degradation. Accordingly, the rate of xylose conversion is expressed as [69]: (1) -r [Xylose] = -d [Xylose]/dt = k [Xylose] = d [Furfural]/dt, where [Xylose] and [Furfural] represent molar concentration of xylose and furfural respectively. k represents the rate constant of xylose dehydration at a specific temperature. According to Arrhenius equation, (2) ln k = −(Ea/RT) + ln A. Substituting (1) in (2), we get, (3) −ln (1-X) = kt + C, where [xylose] is expressed in terms of conversion X. t is the reaction time and C is an arbitrary constant. The linear relationship of the plot of ln (1-X) versus reaction time, t, confirms the assumption of pseudo-first order reaction kinetics for xylose to furfural transformation. The rate constant k, at different temperatures is obtained from the plot of Fig. 10 (a). The Arrhenius plot in Fig. 10(b) is obtained by plotting ln k versus (1000/T). Finally, the activation energy Ea and pre-exponential factor A have been computed in Table 4 . The activation energy of the reaction using the catalyst of MP-2 is 9.96 kcal/mol, which is less than either of the activation energies required for cascaded reaction. Since the activation energy is lower than the energy required for Lewis mediated isomerization reaction of xylose to xylulose, and with the abundant Lewis acidity in the catalyst, it can be fairly proposed that the reaction pathway is a cascaded one initiated by the Lewis acids and completed by the Brønsted acids. In order to test the reusability of the catalyst MP-2 and compare its properties with MIL-101 (Cr), the catalyst has been recovered after each reaction. The used catalyst is washed with toluene to remove the carbonaceous deposits, followed by vacuum drying at 150 °C. The MP-2 exhibits high thermal and hydrothermal stability in contrast to its pristine counterpart MIL-101 (Cr). Though the pure MIL-101 (Cr) has thermal stability up to 350 °C under N2 atmosphere, the structural framework of MOF collapses due to the poor hydrothermal stability of the carboxyl framework in the vigorous reaction conditions (150 °C and high autogenous pressure). Moreover, the pH of the liquid medium after reaction is approximately 2.36. This acidic environment accelerates the hydrolysis of the organic framework of MOF. The MP-2 is successfully recycled for 10 times without any significant loss of activity, whereas, the MIL-101 (Cr) can sustain only 4 cycles of runs of the dehydration reaction, as shown in Fig. 11 (a). A slight drop in catalytic performance in the 8th–10th cycle is mainly due to the coverage of active sites by carbon deposits formed due to humin production. The deposition of carbon is evident from the peak at 2θ = 26.50° in the XRD pattern shown in Fig. 11(b) [70]. It can also be concluded that the crystallinity of recycled MIL-101 (Cr) is lost while that of the recycled MP-2 is preserved. From the ICP results, a total of (1371.05 ppm) 15.83 wt.% of Cr leaching has been detected in case of MIL-101 (Cr) after the 4th run, whereas only 0.404 wt.% Cr leaching (39.03 ppm) have been observed for the composite, after 10 cycles of run. The surface concentration from XPS analysis in Table S3 confirms a rise of 25.78% in carbon content in MIL-101 (Cr) due to the deposition of coke from humins formed during reaction, while carbon enhancement is only 8.34% in case of recycled MP-2 after 10 cycles of run. The high concentration of Brønsted acid sites and pore enlargement effect in the composite allow the forward reaction to proceed rapidly and suppress the coke formation simultaneously. The XPS spectra in Fig. S8 (a) show that Cr peaks in the recycled MIIL-101 (Cr) have been reduced in intensity due to the loss occurred by leaching of the metal, while the hydrothermally stable MP-2 remains as good as the fresh catalyst. The ammonia-TPD profiles of the recycled catalysts in Fig. S8 (b) confirm the previous arguments that the total acidity of the MIL-101 (Cr) follows a setback after 4 cycles of run due to the loss of the main Cr sites. On the other hand, due to its hydrothermal stability, MP-2 retains its acidity after 10 cycles of reaction runs. These characterizations prove that by incorporating SnP nanoparticles into MOF pores, a dual-acidic composite have been developed successfully. The composite shows high catalytic activity and stability towards furfural production from biomass prototype, xylose. 4 Conclusions In summary, this work presents a versatile strategy to develop hydrothermally stable MOF composites with desired Brønsted acidity. The improved properties of such a dual acid MOF hybrid have been demonstrated from the xylose dehydration reaction. Under the vigorous reaction conditions pristine MIL-101 (Cr) degrades after four cycles of reaction runs, but the composite remains stable till ten cycles of reaction runs. Following this strategy, the Lewis to Brønsted acid concentration ratio in the material can be tailored by varying the amount of nanoparticles introduced into the composite. Since the MOF is not subjected to direct acid treatment, hence the integrity of the MOF is maintained. Further research can be executed by incorporating surfactant stabilized nanoparticles for a better distribution of nanoparticles within the composite. Also, varying the nanoparticle and MOF elements can provide an array of dual acidic hydrothermally stable composites that can be used in the field of chemical syntheses and battery. With respect to the current heterogeneous catalysts described for xylose dehydration, the catalyst described in our work fare well above them with respect to the furfural yield and selectivity. Such composites can open up new possibilities to use MOFs in biomass transformations. Conflict of interests The authors declare no conflict of interest. coredata.dc:description: This work presents the development of a new hybrid material composed of metal-organic-framework, MIL-101 (Cr) and mesoporous tin phosphate nanoparticles. The phosphate groups of the composite impart Brønsted acidity, while the Cr and Sn atoms act as the Lewis acid sites, thus promoting it as a dual acid functionalized material suitable for solid acid catalysis of biomass. Simultaneously, the issues of hydrothermal stability and degradation in acidic medium as faced by pristine MIL-101 (Cr), have been fairly alleviated. In order to demonstrate our claims, the composite has been used as a solid acid catalyst for the dehydration of xylose to furfural. A remarkable performance of 86.7% furfural yield with 92.3% selectivity has been achieved in 180 min at 150 °C. The composite can sustain minimum of 10 cycles of run while pristine MIL-101 (Cr) loses its functional properties after 4 cycles of run. In presence of 35 ppt NaCl solution, the yield and selectivity improved to 92.4% and 96.6% respectively.
coredata.dc:title: A dual acidic hydrothermally stable MOF-composite for upgrading xylose to furfural
